I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the country programming exercise conducted in December 2009, the Government of 
the People's Republic of China (PRC) submitted a proposal to request technical assistance (TA) 
from  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  support  a  policy  study  on  strategic  options  for 
urbanization in the PRC1 as part of the government's effort to prepare the 12th Five-Year Plan 
(FYP) for Social and Economic Development 2011–2015. An ADB mission visited the PRC in 
March 2010 and reached an agreement with the government on all the major aspects of the TA 
including impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, 
and terms of reference for consulting service. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 
1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The PRC has made significant progress in economic development since the adoption in 
1978 of the policy for reform and opening of the economy. Over the past 30 years, the economy 
has grown at an annual average rate of more than 9%. The sustained growth in the PRC has been 
accompanied by rapid urbanization resulting from a continuing economic transformation and the 
increasing importance of the economy’s non-agriculture sectors. Cities have become the main 
engine for growth and employment. The number of cities increased from 176 in 1978 to 655 in 
2009. The urban population is expanding at increasing pace: it grew by an average of 10 million 
per year during the 1980s, by 15 million per year in the 1990s, and by 20 million per year since 
2001. However, despite the rapid growth of the urban population, the PRC’s urbanization rate 
remains moderate (about 45.7% at the end of 2008), and is still below the average for middle-
income countries. The country’s rapid urbanization is envisaged to continue, given the growth 
momentum and ongoing economic transformation in the PRC. 
 
3.  Urbanization  in  the  PRC  results  from  economic  development,  and  has  established  a 
foundation to sustain economic development under a set of new conditions. Rapid urbanization 
has created new jobs in the manufacturing and service sectors and provided improved living 
conditions for millions of people, and played a significant role in promoting inclusive growth and 
poverty reduction. Rapid urbanization at such an unprecedented pace and scale has also imposed 
unique development challenges on the PRC. Urbanization is characterized by millions of rural 
people moving into urban areas, rapid expansion of cities and towns (as measured both by urban 
population  and  urbanized  land  area),  and  an  explosive  increase  in  the  demand  for  urban 
infrastructure and municipal services. The situation is compounded in the PRC by the dual public 
management and social service provision established in the 1950s under the planned economy, 
which has effectively divided the population into two separate categories of rural population and 
urban population through the hukou system, i.e. the population registration system.   .    
 
4.  Due to the lack of a national strategy, urbanization in the PRC remains largely a self-driven 
process taking place in hundreds of cities across the country. This process has been accompanied 
by the concerns of migrants in the cities who, due to their rural hukou status, do not have equal 
access  to  public  social  services  provided  by  the  municipal  governments  for  urban  residents; 
uncontrolled urban expansion and loss of agricultural land; intensified frequency of disputes over 
land ownership as well as compensation issues and utility tariff increase;  uncoordinated and 
incoherent urban development among cities of different sizes and economic scales competing for 
limited resources and opportunities; and associated ecological and environmental degradation.

2   
The situation highlights the urgent need to develop a national strategy to guide the ongoing 
urbanization across the country.  
 
5.  At the recently concluded National People's Congress in March 2010, the government once 
again highlighted its commitment to promoting sustained, coherent, and integrated urbanization as 
a  major  strategic  thrust  in  promoting  sustainable  development  in  the  PRC.  In  particular, 
urbanization is expected to play a special role in rebalancing economic growth by strengthening 
domestic demand and economic transformation of the PRC, and building a more balanced and 
diversified economy for sustainable development over the long term. 
 
6.  The FYP is the PRC’s most important instrument in terms of setting a national strategy and 
policy framework to guide social and economic development over a medium-term (5-year) planning 
period. The government is now in the process of preparing the 12th FYP for 2011–2015, which will 
be presented to the National People's Congress for its consideration in March 2011. Past ADB TA 
projects have supported various policy studies at national and sector levels—including the Urban 
Poverty Study I and II, the Town-Based Urbanization Strategy Study, and the Study on Sustainable 
Urbanization in Metropolitan Regions2—and thereby contributed to the development of previous 
FYPs.  For the first time, this TA project will directly involve ADB in the formulation of a nationwide 
strategy as an integral part of the government’s preparation of an FYP. 
 
7.  ADB's  country  partnership  strategy  for  the  PRC  has  highlighted  the  importance  of 
urbanization in promoting inclusive growth and balanced development and has specified that "ADB 
will directly support the sound and sustainable urban development needed to continue urbanizing 
and modernizing the economy".3 With the TA, ADB will promote sound and sustainable urban 
development in the PRC through the provision of support for formulation of a national urbanization 
strategy in the context of the 12th FYP, which will have a long-lasting and far-reaching impact on 
urbanization across the country. The TA will also help ADB clarify its own strategic operational 
focus in the PRC’s urban sector during the 12th FYP period, and form the basis for preparation of 
the urban sector road map for the next country partnership strategy. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the TA will be sustained urbanization in the PRC under the guidance of a 
national urbanization strategy formulated in the context of the 12th FYP. The impact of the TA will 
be measured by the implementation status of the 12th FYP in terms of delivering the urban 
development strategy and the related policy and public intervention measures as outlined in the 
urbanization strategy. 
 
9.  The outcome of the TA will be an urban development strategy for the PRC that is suitable 
for incorporation by the government in the 12th FYP to guide sustained urbanization in the PRC. 
The outcome of the TA will be measured by whether the specific recommendations, proposed in 
the form of a recommended urban development strategy, have been endorsed by the government 
for consideration in formulating the 12th FYP.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The policy study on strategic options for urbanization in the PRC will focus on in-depth and 
systematic analyses of three important urban development issues: (i) the projected pace and 
spatial distribution of urbanization in the PRC, (ii) the emerging urban structural pattern of the 
PRC’s city system across the country, and (iii) the policy and institutional reforms and other 
interventions needed to facilitate coherent, sustainable urban development in the PRC. Special 
attention will be given to the policy and institutional reforms needed to address the challenges 
associated with the massive migration of people from rural to urban areas in terms of providing 
adequate  (i)  basic  infrastructure  such  as  housing,  social  and  municipal  services;  (ii)  public 
employment services; and (iii) social security coverage for the fast-growing urban population. 
 
11.  The policy study will be conducted by an expert team comprising both international and 
national consultants through review of international experiences and best practice, comparative 
analyses of different options under different growth and urbanization scenarios for the PRC as a 
whole and for its major economic zones, and survey and case studies. The TA will also include a 
component for overseas study, which will allow the concerned officials in charge of economic 
planning to have firsthand exposure to different urbanization models, international experiences and 
best practices as part of capacity development for the government. 
 
12.  The outputs of the policy study will be presented in one general report and three theme 
reports as follows: 
 
(i)  General Report: Strategic Options for Urbanization in the PRC 
(ii)  Theme  Report  1:  Comparative  Analyses  of  Different  Growth  and  Urbanization 
Scenarios for the PRC as a whole and for its Major Economic Zones 
(iii)  Theme Report 2: Comparative Analyses of Urban Structural Patterns on Different 
Geographic and Demographic Scenarios of Urbanization for the PRC as a whole 
and for its Major Economic Zones 
(iv)  Theme  Report  3:  Recommended  Policy  and  Institutional  Reforms  and  Public 
Interventions to Support Sustainable Urbanization in the PRC 
 
13.  The  policy  study  will  be  undertaken  collaboratively  by  the  government  and  ADB.  The 
findings of the expert team will be jointly reviewed by the government and ADB at the international 
workshops organized at each of the major TA implementation milestones (i.e., at TA inception, 
midterm review, and wrap-up review), and these findings and views will be taken into consideration 
in preparation of the 12th FYP. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $750,000. The TA will be financed in an amount not 
exceeding $600,000 on a grant basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–other 
sources).  The  government  will  finance  the  remaining  $150,000  equivalent  through  in-kind 
contributions to cover the salary and per diem of its counterpart staff; coordination support for 
surveys, case studies, and workshops and conferences; and access to the data and related 
documents required for the policy study. Detailed cost estimates and a financing plan are in 
Appendix 2.

4   
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) will be the executing agency 
for the TA. The NDRC has designated the director general of the Department for Development 
Planning as the project director to provide overall guidance for implementation of the TA. The day-
to-day operation of the TA will be handled by the Urbanization Planning Division of the Department 
for Development Planning. 
 
16.  The TA will field an expert team whose inputs include 5 person-months of international 
consulting services and 27 person-months of national consulting services for the policy study. The 
international consulting services will include an international urbanization specialist (2 person-
months), international social development specialist (2 person-months), and international urban 
governance  specialist  (1  person-month).  The  national  consulting  services  will  include  a  lead 
urbanization specialist (4 person-months), strategic planning specialist (3 person-months), regional 
planning  specialist  (3  person-months),  urban  governance  specialist  (3  person-months),  social 
development specialist (3 person-months), transport development specialist (3 person-months), 
urban development specialist (2 person-months), environmental planning specialist (2 person-
months), land policy specialist (2 person-months), and low-cost housing specialist (2 person-
months).  
 
17.  Given the importance accorded to the TA in preparation of the 12th FYP, the government 
has requested that the policy study be led by a national consulting firm or research institution that 
has sufficient experience and capacity to deliver high quality outputs relevant to and suitable for 
strategy formulation and decision making. It is agreed that the input and service of each member 
on the expert team will be coordinated by a lead national urbanization specialist who serves as the 
team leader. All the consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The international consulting services will 
be engaged by ADB on an individual basis, while the national consulting services will be engaged 
through a national consulting firm or research institution (i.e., a firm or institution established or 
incorporated in the PRC), using the quality- and cost-based selection method at a quality–cost ratio 
of 90:10 through evaluation of biodata proposals. The outline terms of reference for consulting 
services are in Appendix 3. All the disbursement under the TA will be done in accordance with 
ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.4 
 
18.  TA implementation will start in June 2010 and be completed by 30 June 2011. The TA 
outputs will be published in both English and Chinese.  
 
19.  TA implementation will be subject to both ADB and PRC government project monitoring and 
evaluation  mechanisms.  In  addition  to  routine  monitoring  conducted  against  the  established 
implementation  milestones,  TA  implementation  will  be  the  subject  of  review  missions  jointly 
conducted by the government and ADB. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved  the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government  of  the  People's  Republic  of  China  for  Policy  Study  on  Strategic  Options  for 
Urbanization, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  At the request of the Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC), the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) will provide technical assistance (TA) for a policy study on strategic 
options for urbanization in the PRC. The TA is provided to help the government develop an 
urbanization strategy in formulating 12th Five Year Plan (FYP), which will guide the urbanization 
process in the PRC during the 12th FYP period (2011–2015) and thereafter.  
 
2.  The  National  Development  and  Reform  Commission  (NDRC)  of  the  PRC  will  be  the 
executing agency for the TA. The policy study will be conducted under the guidance of the NDRC 
Department for Development Planning. The TA will provide funding for the expert team that will 
undertake the policy study; inputs will include 5 person-months of international consulting services 
and 27 person-months of national consulting services. The specific inputs and service of each 
member of the expert team will be coordinated by a lead national urbanization specialist, who will 
serve as the team leader. 
 
3.  All the consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The international consulting services will be 
engaged by ADB on an individual basis, while the national consulting services will be engaged 
through a national consulting firm or research institution—i.e., a firm or institution established or 
incorporated in the PRC—using the quality- and cost-based selection method at a quality–cost 
ratio of 90:10 through evaluation of biodata proposals.  
 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  International Urbanization Specialist (2 person-months) 
4.  The  international  urbanization  specialist  shall  have  a  postgraduate  degree  and  have 
knowledge  (as  evidenced  by  research  papers  or  publications)  of  the  global  experience  with 
urbanization, particularly in large-scale, diversified economies similar to or relevant to the PRC 
economy. This expert is expected to: (i) provide knowledge input and research guidance regarding 
major urbanization patterns and strategies in terms of the pace of urbanization, and the geographic 
and demographic features of different city systems among large economies; (ii) provide special 
support in comparative analyses of different urbanization options to be recommended by the expert 
team with an assessment of the impact of the major options recommended; and (iii) provide advice 
and recommendations, based on international best practice, on a suitable urbanization strategy for 
the PRC. In particular, this expert is expected to submit the following two deliverables: (i) a 
background  research  paper  providing  a  summary  analysis  of  international  urbanization 
experiences relevant to urbanization in the PRC; and (ii) a thorough review of each of the following 
documents to be produced by the national consultants, with specific written comments for their 
improvement: interim report, draft final report, and the three thematic papers.    
 
2.  International Social Development Specialist (2 person-months) 
5.  The international social development specialist shall have a postgraduate degree and be an 
expert with solid knowledge (as evidenced by research papers or publications) of international 
experience and best practice in addressing urbanization-related social concerns in large-scale, 
diversified economies similar to or relevant to the PRC economy. These social concerns include, 
among  others,  managing  massive  rural–urban  migration,  provision  of  social  services  and 
affordable  housing  for  an  increasingly  urbanized  population,  provision  of  public  employment 
services and social security coverage for the rapidly increasing urban population, and managing

Appendix 3  9 
the  urbanization-induced  social  impacts  on  rural  families,  the  rural  economy,  and  rural 
development. This expert is expected to provide: (i) knowledge input and research guidance 
regarding international best practices for handling major urbanization-related social concerns, and 
(ii)  special support  for  comparative  analyses  of  different  options  for  public  intervention  to  be 
recommended by the expert team, with an assessment of the impact of the major options. In 
particular, this expert will submit the following two deliverables: (i) a background research paper 
providing  a  summarized  analysis  of  international  urbanization  experiences  in  the  social 
development field that are relevant to urbanization in the PRC; and (ii) a thorough review of each of 
the  following  documents  to  be  produced  by  the  national  consultants,  with  specific  written 
comments for their improvement: interim report, draft final report, and the three thematic papers.    
 
3.  International Urban Governance Specialist (1 person-month) 
6.  The international urban governance specialist shall have a postgraduate degree and be 
knowledgeable (as evidenced by research papers or publications) of international experience and 
best practice in terms of legal frameworks, finance for urban development and provision of social 
services, and government management systems for city development and management. This 
expert is expected to provide knowledge input and research guidance for: (i) comparative analyses 
of different management options for urbanization in the PRC at national, regional, provincial, city 
cluster, or city levels; and (ii) recommendations on policy and/or institutional reforms in urban 
governance in the PRC. In particular, this expert is expected to conduct a thorough review of the 
interim report, draft final report, and the three thematic papers to be prepared by the national 
consultants  with  specific  written  recommendations  for  their  improvement,  from  an  urban 
governance perspective. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
1.  Lead Urbanization Specialist (4 person-months) 
7.  The lead national urbanization specialist will serve as the team leader for the expert team 
and  oversee  and  coordinate  team  members  to  ensure  all  policy  and  technical  studies  are 
completed in a timely manner, and are of good quality. As the lead national urbanization specialist, 
this expert shall have a postgraduate degree and have knowledge (as evidenced by publications 
and/or project experience) of: (i) the complexity of urbanization issues, and (ii) the government’s 
policy formulation procedures and inter-ministerial consultation and decision-making mechanisms. 
This expert will be accountable for the quality of the outputs to be submitted by the national 
consultants,  and  ensure  the  outputs  are  relevant  and  appropriate  for  government  strategy 
formulation and decision making. This expert will be responsible for preparing and finalizing the 
inception report, interim report, draft final report, and final report on behalf of the expert team, and 
submitting the reports to NDRC and ADB.  
 
2.  Strategic Planning Specialist (3 person-months) 
8.  Under the guidance of the team leader, this expert will play a lead role in assessing the 
PRC’s major urbanization options under different economic growth and transformation scenarios, 
with a focus on the pace of urbanization and its interaction with and implication for the overall 
development of the PRC. This expert is expected to develop an urbanization forecast model for the 
PRC, taking into account the PRC’s overall economic development trend and the imbalance that 
exists with respect to the development status of different regions. This expert shall be responsible 
for  preparing  a  theme  report  that  presents  comparative  analyses  of  different  growth  and

urbanization scenarios for the PRC as a whole and for its major economic zones, which should be 
supported with an impact assessment of each of the country’s major strategic options. 
 
3.  Urban Development Specialist (2 person-months) 
9.  Under the guidance of the team leader, this expert will work with the strategic planning 
specialist to conduct a survey and/or case study as an input for the urbanization forecast model. In 
particular,  this  expert  will  provide  comparative  analyses  of  urban  growth  under  different 
circumstances in the PRC—such as in large, medium-sized and small cities and towns—and their 
interactions in an integrated city system. The analyses should include a general assessment of the 
impact of urbanization on the rural economy and rural development in the PRC. Special focus 
should be given to the link between urban growth and the development of urban economies in 
different  types  of  cities.  Taking  into  account  the  international  experiences  provided  by  the 
international consultants, and the findings of the survey and/or case study, this expert will help the 
strategic planning specialist prepare and finalize the theme report on comparative analyses of 
different growth and urbanization scenarios. The findings and recommendations of this expert may 
also be incorporated into the theme report analyzing urban structural patterns associated with 
different geographic and demographic scenarios for the PRC (see para. 10).  
 
4.  Regional Planning Specialist (3 person-months) 
10.  Under the guidance of the team leader, this expert will play a lead role in conducting a 
systematic assessment of the major urbanization options for the PRC under different geographic 
and demographic scenarios, with a focus on the emerging structural patterns of the city system in 
the  PRC,  their  geographic  and  demographic  features  and  their  interactions  with  the  overall 
economic  development  of  the  PRC,  and  their  implications  for  the  country’s  environment  and 
ecosystems.  This  expert  shall  be  responsible  for  preparing  a  theme  report  presenting  a 
comparative  analysis  of  urban  structural  patterns  associated  with  different  geographic  and 
demographic scenarios, both for the PRC as a whole and for its major economic zones. The theme 
report should be supported with an impact assessment for each of the major options available to 
the country. 
 
5.  Transport Development Specialist (3 person-months) 
11.  Under the guidance of the team leader, this expert will work with the regional planning 
specialist in researching the geographic and/or demographic scenarios for urbanization in the PRC. 
Taking into account the international perspective provided by the international consultants, this 
expert will undertake comparative analyses of (i) the transport system development options with a 
view to supporting an integrated city system among the cities in the major economic zones or 
among the major city clusters of the PRC, and (ii) urban transport development scenarios. The 
expert will use these inputs in assisting the regional planning specialist prepare and finalize the 
theme report on urban structural patterns associated with different geographic and demographic 
scenarios.   
 
6.  Environmental Planning Specialist (2 person-months) 
12.  Under the guidance of the team leader, this expert will work with the regional planning 
specialist  to  research  geographic  and/demographic  scenarios  for  urbanization  in the  PRC.  In 
particular, this expert will provide, at the national and strategic level, an initial assessment of the 
environmental implications of different urbanization scenarios and their potential impact on the 
country’s  environmental  and  ecological  system.  The  expert  will  use  these  inputs  to  help  the

Appendix 3  11 
regional planning specialist prepare and finalize the theme report on urban structural patterns 
associated  with  different  geographic  and  demographic  scenarios.  The  findings  and 
recommendations of this expert may also be incorporated into the theme report on recommended 
policy and institutional reforms for the government (see para. 13). 
 
7.  Urban Governance Specialist (3 person-months) 
13.  Under the guidance of the team leader, this expert will play a lead role in conducting a 
specific study on key policy and institutional reforms that are needed to provide an enabling 
environment to support sustained urbanization in the PRC. The specific study should include a 
systematic review of urbanization-related issues, including restructuring of the dual rural–urban 
system, managing massive rural–urban migration, progressive relaxation of the Hukou (residents 
administration) system, finance for urban development, and provision of basic social services 
(including  affordable  housing),  employment  services  and  social  security  for  an  increasingly 
urbanized population. Based on the systematic review, and taking into account the international 
experience and best practice provided by the international consultants, the specific study will make 
recommendations for policy or institutional reforms to support sustained urbanization in the PRC. 
This  expert  will  be  responsible  for  preparing  a  theme  report  on  recommended  policy  and 
institutional reforms for sustained urbanization in the PRC.   
 
8.  Social Development Specialist (3 person-months) 
14.  Under the guidance of the team leader, this expert will work with the urban governance 
specialist, with a focus on preparing recommendations for policy and institutional reforms. In 
particular,  this  expert  will  provide  a  systematic  analysis  of  options  available  to  address  the 
emerging social challenges associated with urbanization, including: (i) the urbanization of migrants 
from rural areas; (ii) provision of essential social services and social security for an increasing 
urban  population,  and  of  employment  services  and  social  security  for  migrant  laborers;  (iii) 
management of urbanization-induced social impacts on rural families, the rural economy, and rural 
development; (iv) identification of the labor market reforms required to facilitate the movement of 
laborers between rural and urban economies and across different regions or sectors; and (v) the 
gender dimension associated with these social concerns. As a social development specialist, this 
expert will help the team conduct and record consultations with stakeholders; they will also help the 
urban governance specialist prepare and finalize the theme report on recommended policy and 
institutional reforms for sustained urbanization in the PRC. 
 
9.  Land Policy Specialist (2 person-months) 
15.  Under the guidance of the team leader, this expert will work with the urban governance 
specialist, with a focus on preparing recommendations for policy and institutional reforms. In 
particular, this expert will provide a systematic review of land policy issues in the PRC, with a 
special focus on the implications for the rural–urban dual system in the PRC  and sustained 
urbanization of the country. This review will include (i) management of urban land, (ii) urbanization 
of peri-urban land, and (iii) policy reforms concerning land acquisition or transfer of land use rights 
as part of urbanization. Based on the review, this expert should provide recommendations to 
address dual system concerns in the PRC from a land reform perspective. With these inputs, the 
expert  will  help  the  urban  governance  specialist  prepare  and  finalize  the  theme  report  on 
recommended policy and institutional reforms for sustained urbanization in the PRC.

12  Appendix 3 
 
10.  Low-Cost Housing Specialist (2 person-months) 
16.  Under the guidance of the team leader, this expert will work with the urban governance 
specialist  in  focusing  on  preparing  recommendations  for  policy  and  institutional  reforms.  In 
particular, this expert will provide a systematic review of the national and international experience 
in providing low-cost housing for an increasing urban population. Based on the review, and taking 
into consideration the international experience and best practice, this expert is expected to provide 
recommendations  on  needed  policy  and  institutional  reforms  to  provide  an  enabling  housing 
environment to accommodate the increasing urban population. With these inputs, the expert will 
help the urban governance specialist prepare and finalize the theme report on recommended 
policy and institutional reforms for sustained urbanization in the PRC. 
 
C.  Deliverables and Submission Schedule 
17.  The expert team is expected to start its field work in June 2010 and submit its major 
deliverables, in both the English and Chinese languages, in accordance with the submission 
schedule: (i) inception report in the first month of mobilization, (ii) draft interim report and draft 
theme reports by the end of the third month of mobilization, (iii) draft final report and draft theme 
reports by the end of the fifth month of mobilization, (iv) final report and final theme reports within 1 
month after receiving government comment,  and (v) report publication within 3 months upon 
submission of the final report.
